question: For which category at the Academy Awards was Head over Heels nominated?

content.source_1:
Here is a Wikipedia-style entry that presents comprehensive evidence for the statement:

**Head over Heels (2012 film)**

**Head over Heels** is a 2012 British stop motion animated short film directed by Timothy Reckart. **Academy Award Nomination**

**Head over Heels** was nominated for the **Academy Award for Best Animated Short Film** at the 85th Academy Awards in 2013. **Evidence**

The nomination was announced by the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences on January 10, 2013. [1] The film was one of five nominees in the Best Animated Short Film category, alongside **Adam and Dog**, **Fresh Guacamole**, **Maggie Simpson in "The Longest Daycare"**, and **Paperman**. [2]

In an interview with **The Guardian**, director Timothy Reckart discussed the film's nomination, stating "It's amazing to be recognized by the Academy, and I'm thrilled to be part of such a talented group of nominees. "[3]

The 85th Academy Awards ceremony took place on February 24, 2013, at the Dolby Theatre in Hollywood, California. Although **Head over Heels** did not win the award, the nomination marked a significant achievement for the film and its director. **References**

[1] Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences. (2013, January 10). Nominations for the 85th Academy Awards. Retrieved from <https:\/\/www.oscars.org\/oscars\/85th-academy-awards-nominations>

[2] The Hollywood Reporter. (2013, January 10). Oscars: 'Lincoln' Leads With 12 Nominations. Retrieved from <https:\/\/www.hollywoodreporter.com\/race\/oscars-2013-lincoln-leads-12-nominations-410111>

[3] The Guardian. (2013, January 11). Oscars 2013: the nominees in full.
content.source_2: As the sun set over the bustling streets of London, Timothy Reckart, the brilliant mind behind the stop-motion animated short film "Head over Heels," sat nervously in his small flat, clutching a worn-out script. It was the night of the 85th Academy Awards, and Timothy's film was up for a nomination in the Best Animated Short Film category. But little did anyone know, there was a peculiar rumor circulating among the animation community - a rumor that "Head over Heels" had also been considered for a nomination in the Best Actor category. Timothy's eyes wandered to a framed photograph on his mantle, featuring the two lead characters from his film, Walter and Madge. The elderly couple, stuck in a gravity-defying world where they lived on opposite sides of the same house, had captured the hearts of audiences worldwide. But what made this film truly special was the way Timothy had brought these characters to life, infusing them with a depth and nuance that was rarely seen in animation. As Timothy's mind began to wander, he recalled a conversation he had with the Academy's nomination committee earlier that year. They had been impressed not only by the film's technical achievements but also by the remarkable performances of Walter and Madge. One committee member had even joked that the couple's on-screen chemistry was more convincing than some of the real-life couples they had seen in live-action films. Timothy chuckled to himself, remembering how he had politely laughed off the comment at the time. But now, as he sat waiting for the Oscar nominations to be announced, he couldn't help but wonder - had the Academy really considered his film for a Best Actor nomination? And if so, what would it mean for the future of animation in the film industry? As the TV screen flickered to life, Timothy's heart skipped a beat as the presenter announced the nominees for Best Animated Short Film. And there, among the list of esteemed films, was "Head over Heels." Timothy let out a sigh of relief, but his mind was still racing with the what-ifs. What if the rumor was true? What if Walter and Madge had indeed been considered for a Best Actor nomination? As the night wore on, Timothy's thoughts were interrupted by the sound of his phone buzzing. It was a text from an old friend, a fellow animator who had been working on a top-secret project in Los Angeles. The message read: "Just got out of a meeting with the Academy.
